displaytitle: Portrait of Jiang Kui of the Song Dynasty
displaydate: 1878 (stone); late 19th to first half of 20th century (rubbing)
medium: Hanging scroll; ink rubbing on paper
markings:
Rubbing seals:
“Yang Jun si yin” 楊浚私印, sq. relief 
“Xuecang” 雪滄, sq. intaglio
inscribed:
Title: 宋姜白石道人小像
Notes: Jiang Kuí 姜夔 (1154-1221), hao: Baishi Daoren 白石道人, also known as “Jiang Baishi.” 

Left of title:
Yang Jun 楊浚 (1830-1890)
宋白良玉寫。嘉慶丙子[1816]十月烏程管以金
所得。道光紀元[1821]三月仁和許乃穀摹本。
光緒戊寅八月侯官楊浚重刊。
Painted by Bai Liangyu of the Song dynasty. In the 10th month of the bingzi cyclical year of the Jiaqing reign [1816], this is what Wu Chengguan obtained with gold. In the 3rd month of the first year of the Daoguang reign, Xu Naigu of Renhe made a copy. In the 8th month of the wuyin cyclical year of the Guangxu reign, recarved by the houguan official Yang Jun.
Notes:
1. Bai Liangyu 白良玉 (act. late12th-early 13th century) was a court painter from Hangzhou who was good at Buddhist and Daoist subjects. 
2. Xu Naigu 許乃穀(谷) (juren 1821), zi: 玉年, native of Renhe. 
3. According to Chen Si’s 陳思 (juren 1902), Baishi Daoren nianpu 白石道人年譜 (1934), as recorded in the　
【太廟齋郎】 。。。烏程管以金跋云：「嘉慶丙子冬十月既望余於郡城觀風巷口購得古人像殘縑尺許題詞剝蝕僅存風情賦芳草五字歸以硯北雜志校之始知是白石道人也時嚴丈修能倪丈米樓歎為希世珍藏弆經年吾友姜君玉溪見而愛之云道人乃其二十三世祖此像世藏弁山之寥天一碧樓乾隆辛卯樓遭鬱攸之災遂遺失人閒今幸落余手因再三乞贈余思道人一代詞宗超前軼後像垂六百年而面目無損謂非天之呵護有不爽耶輒允其請而割愛歸之頃玉溪屬仁和許君玉年臨摹一本壽諸樂石將供奉於孤山林處士祠。。。」白石之先世後裔可考見者略具於此世系表出於後裔之手似尤可據惟嚴杰白石小傳云八世祖泮世系表泮為白石七世祖相差一世傳云泮饒州教授即家鄱陽表云泮家上饒案鄱陽屬饒州上饒屬信州同治上饒縣志選舉進士紹興八年戊午黃公度榜徐作則姜俊民表云泮家上饒其以此歟俟求九真姜氏家譜再詳考之德興縣志乾道五年己丑鄭僑榜姜廓上饒縣志淳熙十四年丁未王容榜姜嚴德興上饒疆埸 
http://www.guoxue123.com/other/lhcs/lhcs/378.htm (accessed 3/21/2020)
[for Wu Chengguan’s quoted inscription see Comparanda, rubbing sold a Burkowskis auction, below]

titles.title: Portrait of Jiang Kui of the Song Dynasty

makers.displaymaker: Yang Jun 楊浚, carving agent, 1830–1890

texts.textentryhtml: Seated figure of Jiang Kui (1154-1221), a poet, composer, poetry theorist and calligrapher of the Song dynasty. Jiang is portrayed sitting on a chair holding a feather fan. A title and inscription are added at upper left. The inscription records that this portrait follows an image attributed to the Song dynasty court painter Bai Liangyu 白良玉 (act. late12th-early 13th century), which was purchased by Wu Chengguan in 1816 and copied by Xu Naigu 許乃穀 (juren 1821). In 1821, Yang Jun had this copy, omitting the inscriptions on the earlier version.

bibliography.boilertext: "Recent Acquisitions," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 18, no. 1 (1959): p. 40-42.
bibliography.citation: "Recent Acquisitions," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 18, no. 1 (1959): p. 40-42., p. 42
